summary.title: [CP02] Threat Modeling - Cagaoan & Salazar
summary.owner: John Henry Cagoan & Jacob Israel Salazar

text.text:
grant access or allows
the attack to spoof
identity

gain unauthorized
access to the
database

take control of the
Web server

obtains the
encryption keys used
to encrypt sensitive
data

unauthorized access
to Web server
resources and static
files

Information is
disclosed and
sensitive exception
details

Data Access -
Business Components
Trust Boundary

use hash algorithms
recommended by
OWASP such as
Argon2id, bcrypt,
PBKDF2 to hash

limit failed login
attempts by through
time-locks

support captcha use to
deter brute force attacks

do not store plaintext
passwords in the
database

Include a password
strength meter to assist
users to create a more
complex password and
minimize reusing

diagrams.title: Threat Graph 2 - Network Eavesdropping &  Captures an Authentication Cookie

text.text:
Attacker executes MITM
to capture client data or
authentication cookies

use only secure
protocols and disable
legacy protocols to
minimize use of
non-encrypted

use signed cookies and
employ expiration times
to allow users to
authenticate

diagrams.title: Threat Graph 3 - SQL injection and Cross-Site Scripting

text.text:
Failure to encode output
leading to potential

Failure to sanitize data
read from a shared

Attacker inputs
malicious code in input
boxes, resulting to SQL
injection or cross-site
scripting attacks

Missing or weak input
validation at the server

Use supplementary
libraries to handle buffer
overflows prior to
forwarding data to
business logic

Use of regex and
server-side AJAX to
block invalid user input

Immediately return
generic error message
for invalid user input

Escape output data to
make the data
user-friendly, particularly
if data read will be used
by other data

Use auxiliary libraries to
encode output retrieved
from database

Exposing exception
details to the client

Attacker discloses
information and senstive
exception details to the
client

Create an error handler
that returns generic
error messages to the
client

Exposing an
administration function
through the
customer-facing Web
application.

Reroute exception
details to logs that are
only accessible via the
web server interface

Drop critical data
retrieved from server if
an error is encountered

diagrams.title: Threat Graph 5 - Attacker Gains Access to Web Server

text.text:
Attacker gains access to
web server, run
commands in database
and modify web server
resources and static files

Mishandled physical
security controls in web
server premise

Employ rotating
credentials to ensure
that old administrator
login details are
rendered unusable

Disable destructive
database actions such as
modifying multiple
documents at once or
dropping tables

Employ regular server
backups or snapshots to
easily rollback to
versions prior to data
compromises

Re-run background
checks for employees
with access to the web
server
